column1: Before 26 December 2020, will the Australian government accuse the Chinese government, by name, of being behind the "copy-paste compromises" cyberattacks?
column6: ['Technology', 'Foreign Policy', 'Security and Conflict']
I guess $ count more than truth. While still a fan of Ozzies in general, they aren’t the Ozzies I knew in past. I miss one of my footy lads screaming “Ozzie Ozzie Ozzie oi oi oi!”...
Strategy appears to be not to name names as the situation is inflamed enough as it is.
It seems unlikely considering they knew it was a "state-based" actor since June and did not say which state yet. With such a short time frame, I have to go with less than 1% chance this will happen.
time almost up now
Less and less likely by the day.

Time is running out for this to occur. On the other side, rhetoric has heated up lately between the two countries. Therefore happy to say there's a non-zero chance of this occurring, but the time left is minimal

Unnamed officials have blamed China, but so far nothing specific from the PM or cabinet ministers. It's still possible Australia will call out China before December 26, but it seems like if it was going to happen it would have happened by now. Seems unlikely.
Winnie the Pooh just doesn’t have a sense of humour... https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-11-03/china-to-halt-key-australian-commodity-imports-as-tensions-mount

tensions have eased, and not much time left until the end date. However these things can happen quickly and unexpectedly (ie. by definition cyber attacks happen quickly and unexpectedly). So still a small outside chance of an attack happening and Australia therefore accusing China accordingly.

https://www.abc.net.au/news/2020-09-04/cyber-attacks-on-australia-peace-war-defence-minister/12626396 Federal government officials have indicated that China is behind cyber attacks against Australia, which is not the PM or his Ministers and avoiding any diplomatic incidents, one assumes.

Minister for HA Peter Dutton has given Australia a heightened warning in regards to cyber attacks on critical infrastructure. https://www.smh.com.au/politics/federal/consequences-catastrophic-dutton-says-cyber-attacks-on-critical-infrastructure-rising-20201021-p56732.html
Winnie The Pooh does not take kindly to even potential insults. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-10-12/australia-dials-up-beijing-seeking-clarity-on-coal-import-ban
if found it will be covered up
very unlikely
Down to 0%. Aussie politician (as opposed to general population) cowards!

Australia has to run a narrow diplomatic line between upsetting its largest trading partner (who else will buy its commodity produce) who provide 49% of total exports and issues concerning a troubling foreign interference into its political structures. Relations are low at he moment given tit-for-tat detaining of journalists based in each other’s countries and China’s face-saving reaction to Australia’s request for a study into the origin of Covid-19. A Dirk van der Kley form the China Matters* think tank based in Canberra has advocated the hiring of a ‘Foreign Interference Commissioner” to be based at the Australian Human Rights Commission. Given the title of the think tank, there is only one foreign country they are thinking about, but the Human rights angle seems odd. Such a position/department would possibly monitor the situation without handing out accuations. Cyber attacks can be used anonymously or to send a message without the collateral damage, but not necessary to raise the diplomatic temperature. My proposal is that accusations will have little value at this time and have reduced the likelihood accordingly.

There have been growing tensions between China and Australia during the COVID pandemic, particularly around a formal investigation of the source. Additionally, Australian journalists are being held in China for reasons not released to the public. The TikTok app has also been topical and related to China. This tension could contribute to the Australian government mentioning China as the source however, there may be more of a restriction to specifically name the Chinese government. Lifting the likelihood of any reports directly naming the China government was the recent change to Australia’s extradition treaty with Hong Kong in response to fears over a new national security law imposed by China. The Chinese Government urged the Australian government to immediately stop involving themselves in these issues, with a threatening style quote deriving from the Chinese Embassy: “…otherwise it will lead to nothing but lifting a rock only to hit its own feet". Because of the length of time since PM Morrison reported this to media (June 2020) and the growing tensions between China and Australia, there is an increased chance someone in the Australian Government will identify the Chinese Government as responsible for the attack. In contrast, the clandestine nature in which ASD operate, and the number of escalating factors involved, there may be an increased level of caution in identifying the Chinese Government for fears of an ongoing feud and retribution (so the probability must be below 50%), however if there is significant evidence, Australia is unlikely to hold back. It is likely Australia will only use estimative language in any accusations against the Chinese Government. In this sense of the question, they will not directly accuse China (and provide 0% chance) but there have been examples in the past where Australia has stated: “China is likely behind the sustained cyber attack” and “One expert says there has been increased espionage activity looking to extract material related to COVID-19”. This increases the probability of this scenario occurring.
Lowering for passage if time.
It's not happening is it?!

Has become a non-issue over the last month or so. Federal government is unlikely to want to goad China given the trade bans China has implemented recently. https://www.abc.net.au/news/2020-08-19/china-eyes-australian-wine-export-in-latest-trade-move/12571672

Want to illuminate a concept. This is a "carry trade", something used by currency traders when they invest in a currency returning a higher interest rate. It's a low short term risk but high long term risk trade.

There is a tit for tat, but this is unlikely.
Seems like there is further verbal escalation, raising for the possibility that Australia respond in the near future.
Lowering by 10%.

Out of the 24 countries who have been victims of cyber warfare on the Wikipedia page for Chinese intelligence activity abroad, only 2 of them (the US and Belgium) have actually called out China directly by name. (1)
Lowering confidence due to the below article which in its essence was:

China is a huge trading partner to Australia and I don’t expect Australian government to jeopardize this further by making direct accusation to China. Unless forced by their Western allies (US primarily). I give 20% at this point, considering that Australians would leave the tension to ease, rather than adding fuel to the fire.
Source 1 shows us that Australia has begun their vocalisation of China actions, in this instance regarding the South China Sea claim.

Nothing in the media
With the UK and US going in on China and calling them out. Aus must feel compelled to stand up for their position in the coming weeks.

The media are declaring that China is responsible for the cyber-attacks on Australian systems. The Australian government has stated that the attacks were carried out by state actors such as Russia, Iran, North Korea and China. Morrison has essentially issued a warning that the State is known and want it stopped. China appears to be beyond embarrassment with its growing superpower status. Whether or not the Australian Government name China as the source of the cyber-attack depends on the level of tension between Australia and China and the pressure by the international community concerning Covid-19, Hong Kong, Spratly Islands, Indian border etc. It is conceivable that given the vocal potential of Australian Senators that China could be named in Parliament that force the Government into clarifying their position. The Australian Government has joined others in naming Russia in hacking Covid-19 researchers in the west. Therefore, with backing from its allies, Australia could name China directly. I propose a 40% chance of the Australian Government naming China directly by 26 December 2020.
There are other possible countries behind this Attack, example north Korea. Australia is very cautious about international issues for that reason I think they could not accuse China.
Better left unsaid. The moment is gone and there are lots of other things to say.
Lowering for passage of time. Australia mentioned state actor but not who. Put out specific information on to combat copy paste attack.

Australia could simply name China in the media, or be more effective and utilize the Copy-Paste attacks as a platform to draw talent out of China/Hong Kong. The recent Visa declaration aimed at immigrating high talent HK’s and directly benefit the Aussie nation economically pains China.

Pure economics, Australia cannot rely on the US, England the EU are courting money from China, so eventually Australia will have to tone down keep the facts to a behind the scenes negotiation and publicly keep it quiet. For the Australian economy is all about selling in China, so staying quiet in public and allow the Chinese save face, it is the path on a technical spat.

Decreasing from 10 to 5. It's now fair to say other events (Hong Kong visa, student warnings) have filled the news cycle and this issue is a memory. The chances of a minister accidentally naming China with relation to this specific attack is now very very low.
Australia is escalating on tensions further:
https://www.bbc.com/news/world-australia-46096768
News that Australia took part in South China Sea training exercises with the US which seems to make the case they are still doing things to push back on China without outwardly naming them.

I can find no mention in online reports of an official investigation and report to be published. Yet another indication that the Chinese will not be accused by name. Morrison has made it clear who he thinks it is but with so much trade at stake has to tread lightly. As others have already pointed out, you can never rule out a cabinet minister blurting it out so unless unforeseen events occur a low probability remains.
Seems unlikely given that the Federal government has refused to name China to date. There is no inquiry into the attacks which seems most the likely platform to name China.

I can only see this being done in the context of a further worsening of the relationship - potentially over Hong Kong, as the world already knows who Australia meant. For now hard to see the motivation from Australia in escalating
Newsflash...China was responsible.

Offiical institutions have already declared the acts to be state-sponsored. Some indirect reports from ACSC and others tend to suggest that similar patterns from Chinese threat actors were previously identified and reported. However, while limited publicly available information make it hard to say with certainty that China is that state sponsor, the reluctance of the Australian govt. to name China may be the strongest indicator that it could be China. There has been a pattern of hostile behaviour between both countries. Australian officials may be waiting to a) get solid evidence, or b) may be anticipating adverse consequences or c) may not be in what they view to be the right position to face the backlash following the statement. As such, the odds that Australia accuses China are probably hoovering at between 25 and 55%. 50% seems to be a fair compromise today.
Enough number of supporters of Chinese government within the rich and powerful in Australia to pressure the Australian government to not do this.

Unlikely for them to call out on their own when they have better ways to call out China without such tradeoff.. Unless information is released which is widely and publicly available between now-Nov - most possibly by legit and non-state sources - then I will increase my probability to 14%. Possible for opposition to do so, more than the govt.
Value of directly naming unclear and would increase potential of further actions in cyber or other domain (e.g. trade).

7/2/2020 - Morrison and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi signed a military pact allowing each country to utilize the other's military bases (further military escalation; greater chance an enemy is named) [8]

2015 - Australia blaims China for spying, which China denies. 2019 - More tension between Australia and China and more cyberattacks. PM also blaims a sophisicated state actor, which would strongly imply China.

7/1/2020 - Morrison announces significant increase in military budget; does not say explicitly that the reason is China, but it is assumed that it is (increased tensions; increased chance that ministers actually name an enemy) [7]
Difficulty of substantiating attribution, especially to government actors
The tendency of states to name China for these actions is low. Impact on trade is high and the effect of China's influence on other states in the region will be detrimental to AUS and its economy.
They are investing tons of money in cybersecurity. They will find out a lot more about it.
There has been a lot of good analysis on this thread with many good links. Nothing I have from my brief learning is ground breaking. My few thoughts though to look back on:
Surely some cabinet minister will accidentally name them

- Strong history of the PM and his cabinet not naming China, but instead referring to the culprit as a "state-actor" [1][2] - Peter Jennings, Executive Director of the ASPI, has named China outright, but he is not apart of the cabinet-level, though presumably he reports to the Minister of Defense [3] - Seems to be general fear over damaging relationships with China [4] - General conclusion by the media, based on statements from unnamed government officials point to China, indicating that the government likely knows that it is them [5] - Scott Morrison has named foreign governments as the culprits of cyber attacks in the past, namely he blamed Russia for meddling in the 2016 U.S. Presidential Election (much different than blaming China, however, as they don't have significant economic ties with the country) [6]

It is incredibly unlikely that Australia will publicly name China as responsible for these cyber-attacks. This type of action would, most likely, bring additional Chinese pressure against Australia and Australia does not need to name China to let China know that Australia knows what China is doing [1]. Further, Australia has a history of not naming China when the country knows that China has conducted cyber attacks in the past [2]. Finally, The Australian government has publicly called for an investigation into the COVID-19 pandemic, which offended China[3]. Finally, as Australia is dependent on China for trade, and both countries are engaged in "cold" trade war[4], it is unlikely that the Australian government will take economic risks by publicly calling out China as the attacker of these cyber attacks.

They don't need to publicly. The coalition government will not risk further tantrums from China that have real (and headline grabbing) economic impacts by actually naming and shaming. I'm leaving the 10% potential there because David Speers might catch a minister off guard on a Sunday morning. ;)

China is the nemesis du jour. Too many stories of espionage, genocide, info cover up, etc. Not saying those items are founded in untruths but makes them a target nonetheless. Not to mention the unknown attraction to xenophobia that seems to be infecting the world.

As all suspect it is china already there is absolutely zero to be gained in pointing it out. Best to lie back and think of England to borrow a phrase. One does not want to upset the few remaining horses.

Australia has, in recent times shown, no qualms in opposing China on the international stage. Given that the evidence of the insofar anonymous state-actor being China is bound to grow to a point where the claim can be made with reasonable certainty in the scope of the next few months, Australia has no incentive to not bring this matter as lucidly as possible to get ensure other countries make a note of it

Morrison doesn't have leverage, Aus far too reliant on chinese for exports. More likely cabinet-level minister will name, so am going with 20% because of that.
